content: Is this password preceded by oauth://? That is the token stored in Saved Passwords after OAuth2 authentication has completed with Yahoo.

content: If you access the account in webmail, is there a Junk folder? If there is, the mail provider is applying filters before mail is downloaded to TB. Consider whitelisting or unblocking senders in webmail, and add safe senders to webmail contacts.
creator: sfhowes

content:
You'll need to add an additional folder mode to force the unified folder heading to appear. So modified instructions...

  • Install https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/addon/unified-folders-debugging/
  • If you do not see the "Unified Folders" heading in the folder pane, then click on "..." next to "New messages", click "Folder Modes", enable an additional folder mode to force the "Unified Folders" heading to appear
  • click on "..." next in the "Unified Folders" heading
  • click Debugging Info > scroll to bottom > click Copy to Clipboard and save the clipboard somewhere
  • Click Close.
  • Click "Reset Unified Folders" in the Unified Folders heading.

Does that help?
creator: wsmwk

content: Enable Unified Folders under View/Folders from the 3-bar AppMenu, click the 3-dot icon next to Unified Folders in the Folder Pane and select Reset Unified Folders (see picture).

content: You are out of line and ill-informed and not worthy of my help. Yes, when a user reports a problem that has no relationship to an email client (Thunderbird or any other), I advise them how to resolve their issue. Forgot password? Not us. Lost server configuration? Not ours. Deleted profile? Unfortunate. Banned? I provide links to pursue. Profile upgrade? I assist. Profile migration? Ditto. Configuration error? Assist provided. I have responded over 8,000 times and I doubt you have followed any of the substantive ones, such as the ones where I stick with a user for a week or more of emails to fix a serious problem. So, bug out on your criticisms. You attack that Thunderbird removes addons with no knowledge, other than your anger. Fix your anger management problem.

content:
OK, so the "Manually Sort Folders" add-on was not created by Thunderbird, got it. Still, they claim this newer version is supposed to make things easier so why can't they create something like that? You can "unify" folders and set "favorite" folders, etc. so you would think there would be a way to put them where you need them in the order that you need them.

On a personal note: People use these forums because they have problems they would like actual HELP with, they would like practical ways to accomplish the things they need by people who actually have involvement in the productivity of the product (here being Thunderbird).

Not really trying to be rude, but I have read several of your answers to several different types of questions over the years and your answer is always basically the same ... it's someone else's problem, not a Thunderbird problem .... so ... Do you work for Thunderbird? You are listed as a "Contributor". Do you even actually report any of these problems or ideas TO Thunderbird so they can review them or do you simply offer your "two-cents" and expect everyone to to just roll with it?

content: Just to clarify: addons are developed by individual developers. Thunderbird has no authority over them. If an addon is popular and the author receives occasional donations, then author may continue its support, but that's an author decision.

content:
studio82 ha detto
Salve, in modalità risoluzione dei problemi mi funziona correttamente lo scrolling, lascio cosi?

È probabile che sia un problema di compatibilità con la scheda grafica. Verifica anzitutto se esistono driver più aggiornati. Se così non risolvi, in Tasto menu > Impostazioni > Generale c'è una opzione per disattivare l'accelerazione hardware

Ovviamente puoi avviare Thunderbird normalmente.

L'altra ipotesi, ma credo che sia meno probabile, è che tu abbia installato qualche estensione che interferisce con le funzionalità del mouse.

content:
All I can do is give my advice as I have set 115 up. Others may offer other suggestions. My suggestion is this: - rightclick the unified toolbar and click 'customize' - drag all the buttons you would normally use, such as get messages, write, forward, delete, etc - if menu bar is on, click view>toolbars and UNtick it - click view>folders and UNtick the folder pane header (This is optional. I happen to like that header, but omitted from my screenshot to give you a view close to 102.)

Now you have a clean view. Instead of menu bar, you have the hamburger menu in upper right. This view is now close to 102, but in doing so, you lose some of the features of the folder pane header. This new design completely removes the need for the old menu bar and gives you full control of what features you want. Okay, I may seem biased, but I was like you at first. I didn't like the view and I insisted on keeping the menu bar. Now, I prefer the new view. And THANKS for being open to this change. So many post here with anger that the view is different. True, it's different, but is very flexible.
creator: davidsk

content:
sfhowes said
In Settings/Privacy & Security, Saved Passwords, is there an smtp:// entry for the O365 account?

No, there isn't. There is only one entry there: oauth://login.microsoftonline.com (https://outlook.office.com/IMAP.AccessAsUser.All https://outlook.office.com/POP.AccessAsUser.All https://outlook.office.com/SMTP.Send%20offline_access).

I have tried deleting that one entry. After doing that that when it next needs to contact Microsoft for IMAP it prompts me for a new OAuth2 login, as expected. But it doesn't have any effect on Thunderbird's behaviour when sending emails. In particular it doesn't display an OAuth2 login for smtp.

But your comment did trigger an idea for me. I temporarily changed the IMAP login to "Normal Password" leaving smtp on OAuth2, deleted the login password mentioned above and then pressed [Send] on an email. I wanted to see what smtp does when it has no way to authenticate. It results in the OAuth2 login being displayed with a URL like https://login.microsoft.com/common/oauth2/v2.0/authorize?responde_type=code&client_id=....&redirect_uri=https%3A%2F%2Flocalho..., which immediately redirects a couple of times ending up at https://idp.DOMAIN.NAME/simplesaml/saml2/idp/SSOService.php. That page is blank, and after a second or so it disappears without asking for input. But the oauth:// password entry is recreated nonetheless, and looks to be valid because when I revert the IMAP login to OAuth2 I don't get prompted to get a new OAuth2 bearer token. So sending with SMTP is traipsing down the OAuth2 path, but in the end it fails in the way I described in my first post. Ie, it presents the dialogue with then [Enter New Password] button.
creator: russell+accounts.firefox.com

content: In Settings/Privacy & Security, Saved Passwords, is there an smtp:// entry for the O365 account? If there is, delete it, restart TB, and you should see the OAuth window, where you enter the account (not app) password for the account. If there's also an imap:// entry in Saved Passwords, delete it. There should only be a single oauth:// entry after successful OAuth authentication.
creator: sfhowes
